abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Economic and
            Social Reunification Support Project (PUSPRES) for
            Democratic Republic of Congo were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high, the
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: introduction of flexibility
            mechanisms at the design level in emergency projects is
            essential to allow responses to adapt to rapidly changing
            needs. Emergency projects are prepared in a short time in
            order to quickly produce significant impacts on the ground,
            and the valuable database necessary to make a good
            evaluation is usually not available. The case of PUSPRES is
            a perfect example. Thus, it is necessary from design to
            introduce flexibility mechanisms to adapt to changing needs
            and fill the gaps resulting from shortened preparation
            times. This flexibility should also be reflected in the
            provision of adequate resources to deal with the inevitable
            cost overruns. Proactive restructuring of post-conflicts
            projects is a good alternative to mitigate the weaknesses in
            the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework and of
            project design considering the fact that emergency
            operations will always suffer from design weaknesses. The
            M&E framework is often overlooked in emergency projects
            which are more focused on physical reconstruction efforts
            than on monitoring impacts. PUSPRES used the restructuring
            component to set up a stronger M&E framework.
